headings: Overview > Triggers Based on Stages
body:
Account and contact stages are associated with triggers that automate responses in a sequence. Triggers can be edited for each stage.
To customize contact stage triggers, launch Apollo and click Settings .
Click Contacts in the "Configurations" section.
To edit a trigger for a Contact Stage , click Triggers to see your list of triggers.
Click the drop-down to change the trigger for your stage.
To customize account stage triggers, launch Apollo and click Settings .
Click Accounts in the "Configurations" section.
To edit a trigger for an Account Stage , click Triggers to see your list of triggers.
Click the drop-down to change the trigger for your stage.
For more information on triggers, please read Use Stage Triggers to Manage and Track Sales Engagement .
title: Contact and Account Stages Overview

headings: Overview
body:
Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting & Conformance (DMARC) is a standard email authentication method that helps you prevent hackers from spoofing your organization for malicious purposes and allows you to limit sent emails to those authenticated by your organization. DMARC's most basic function is to tell receiving email servers what to do with outgoing messages from your domain that don’t pass the Sender Policy Framework (SPF) or Domain Keys Identified Mail (DKIM) checks. Setting up DMARC also allows you to generate reports to make sure your emails aren't being spoofed.
Refer to the sections below to verify and configure your DMARC settings.
title: Set Up Domain-based Message Authentication Reporting and Conformance (DMARC) to Authenticate Your Emails
labels: Domain-based Message Authentication Reporting and Conformance

headings: Overview > Verify DMARC Configuration
body:
Usually, your domain's DMARC policies are set by your IT rep or domain/mail administrator, but you can also check them yourself with a tool like MX Toolbox .
Within MX Toolbox, enter your domain name in the search bar and click DMARC Lookup .
The Result column shows your current DMARC configuration.
You have now verified your DMARC configuration.
title: Set Up Domain-based Message Authentication Reporting and Conformance (DMARC) to Authenticate Your Emails
labels: Domain-based Message Authentication Reporting and Conformance

headings: Overview > Enable DMARC for Your Domain
body:
If you've followed the steps above and found a DMARC record , there is no need to enable or configure it any further. If the tool did not find a record, refer to the steps below to enable DMARC .
Enabling DMARC for your domain ultimately depends on your domain or email provider. Some popular providers include Google Workspace and Microsoft Office 365 . If you use either of these providers, you can refer to links below to confirm the settings and enable DMARC .
- Google Workspace:
- Before You Set Up DMARC
- Define your DMARC Policy
- Add Your DMARC Record
- Tutorial: Recommended DMARC Rollout
- DMARC Reports
- Troubleshoot DMARC
- Office 365:
- Use DMARC to validate email
title: Set Up Domain-based Message Authentication Reporting and Conformance (DMARC) to Authenticate Your Emails
labels: Domain-based Message Authentication Reporting and Conformance

headings: Overview > Fix Other Possible Spam Issues
body: DMARC policies are only one part of making sure your emails are being delivered. You should also set up Sender Policy Framework (SPF) records and Domain Keys Identified Mail (DKIM) to further validate your organization's domain and prevent email bounces.
title: Set Up Domain-based Message Authentication Reporting and Conformance (DMARC) to Authenticate Your Emails
labels: Domain-based Message Authentication Reporting and Conformance

headings: Overview
body:
Default cards (Technologies, Job Postings, Funding Rounds, and Score Breakdown) are available in all account and contact profile layouts. Custom Field Cards allow you to display information on a profile page for custom fields that you've configured in Apollo.
 
Learn More About Creating Custom Fields
For additional information about creating custom fields, please see the " Create Custom Contact Fields ," " Create Custom Account Fields ," and " Create Custom User Fields " articles.
Refer to the section below for information about how to create and display a custom field card on an account or contact profile.
title: Add Custom Field Cards

headings: Overview > Create a Custom Field Card
body:
Launch Apollo, click Search on the navbar, and then click People or Companies .
Click on the name of the contact or account that you want to create a Custom Field Card for.
Click the Edit drop-down in the cards section.
Click Edit Layout to show the "Cards" menu.
Click Custom Fields Cards .
Next, click Create Custom Field Card .
In the modal, enter a Card Name and Card Description .
Expand the accordions to show the Available Fields options. Select the "Contact" and "Account" fields that you want for your card.
 
Custom Fields
Please note, if you don't see the field that you want, create a new custom field.
Click Save .
Apollo automatically adds the new card to the layout for the respective contact or account. Fill in any relevant details for the card. If you need to remove the card, click the trash can icon.
Hover your mouse over the Custom Field Card to see the options for Add to Board , Edit Card , or Delete Card .
title: Add Custom Field Cards

headings: Overview > Add Custom Field Cards to Your Layout
body:
To add existing field cards to your layout, navigate to a contact or account profile and click the Edit drop-down in the "Overview" section.
Click Edit Layout to show the "Cards" menu.
Click Custom Fields Cards .
Hover your mouse over an existing Custom Field Card and click + Add to Board .
title: Add Custom Field Cards

headings: Overview > Edit Custom Fields in Your Cards
body:
From the contact or account profile page, click the Edit drop-down in the "Overview" section.
Click Edit Layout to show the "Cards" menu.
Click Custom Fields Cards .
Hover your mouse over an existing Custom Field Card and click Edit Card .
Expand the accordions to show the Available Fields options. Select the "Contact" and "Account" fields that you want for the card.
After editing the fields, click Save .
title: Add Custom Field Cards

headings: Overview
body:
When you create a sequence and add contacts to it , you need to consider which mailbox you want to use to reach your contacts . By default, this could be the mailbox you linked directly to your user name, but there may be instances when you need to change this to another mailbox linked to your account.
There are many locations in the platform where you can change your linked mailbox :
- The "Contacts" page
- Individual Contact records
- The "Emails" tab in a sequence
- The "Emails" tab in the Engage section
The sections below highlight 3 of the easiest ways to update which mailbox you use to email contacts from Apollo.
 
Change a Linked Mailbox
Please note, you can update a linked mailbox at any time. The mailbox you link is not permanent.
title: Update a Linked Mailbox in a Sequence

headings: Overview > Add Contacts to a Sequence and Select a Linked Mailbox
body:
You can select a linked mailbox when you add a contact to a sequence . Launch Apollo, hover your mouse over Search in the navbar, and then click People .
Add filters to your search to find the right people for the sequence .
Use the checkbox to select the contact(s) .
Click the Sequence drop-down.
Then click Add to Sequence .
Next, click the Sequence drop-down in the Add to Sequence modal and select the sequence to which you would like to add the contact(s) .
Click View all sequences if you want to open a new tab to review all your options from the Sequences page.
Click the Send Emails From: drop-down and click the email address you would like to use to email the newly added contacts .
Then, click Add now to immediately add your contact(s) to the sequence with the selected mailbox.
If you don't want to add the contact(s) to the sequence right away, you can schedule when Apollo adds them. First, click Schedule .
Then, click the radio button next to your preferred scheduled time or manually select a custom date and time for which you want Apollo to add the contacts to the sequence .
Click Schedule .
You have now added contact(s) to a sequence and selected a linked mailbox .
 
Adding a Contact to a Sequence
For more information on how to add contacts to a sequence , please see Add Contacts to a Sequence .
title: Update a Linked Mailbox in a Sequence

headings: Overview > Update the Linked Mailbox for a Contact in a Sequence
body:
Once you add contacts to a sequence , you can change the linked mailbox at any time.
Launch Apollo, hover your mouse over Engage in the navbar, and then click Sequences .
Click the Sequence for which you want to edit a contact's linked mailbox .
Click Contacts to display the sequence contacts list.
Click the checkbox next to a contact or contacts to select them.
Click ... and then click Email From Different User .
In the modal, use the In the current sequence, send emails from: drop-down to select a linked email address.
When you're finished, click Save .
You have now changed the linked mailbox for a contact in a sequence .
title: Update a Linked Mailbox in a Sequence

headings: Overview > Update the Linked Mailbox for Any Email
body:
Once you have sent an email, you can choose to re-send from a different user or to update the sender for all subsequent sequence steps.
Launch Apollo, click Engage , and then click the Emails tab.
Click the checkbox(es) on the left of each email that you want to select and then click Email from Different User .
In the modal, use the Send emails from: drop-down to select a linked email address.
Click the If a scheduled email is in an active sequence, would you like to change the send from email for subsequent steps as well? drop-down.
Then, select Email from different user for subsequent steps in sequence as well if you want to change the linked mailbox for the selected contact(s) for all remaining steps in the sequence.
Alternatively, click Only email from different user for the selected emails if you want to change the linked mailbox for the selected emails only.
Click Email from Different User .
You have now updated the linked mailbox for any email in any sequence.
 
Choose Your Mailbox Wisely, Folks!
Have you selected a Microsoft Exchange mailbox that you did not create in your name? If so, please note that when you send an email the name of the mailbox owner may appear as the sender in the recipient’s inbox. If you want to continue using this mailbox, consider adjusting your Microsoft Exchange settings first. Please refer to the Manage User Mailboxes article in the Microsoft Knowledge Base for more information about user settings. Alternatively, select a Microsoft Exchange mailbox that you created in your name or use any other connected mailbox from a supported email service provider . Apollo recommends sending your emails from a Gmail mailbox to get the most out of Apollo’s functionality.
title: Update a Linked Mailbox in a Sequence

headings: Overview
body:
Domain Keys Identified Mail (DKIM) is an authentication method that uses cryptography to add an encrypted digital signature to your organization's outgoing emails. In this method, your mail server uses a private key to encrypt the email data and receiving email servers retrieve the corresponding public key to decrypt it. This ensures that your email is genuinely sent from your domain and hasn’t been altered on its way to the recipient. It also raises your spam score, which increases the chances of your emails being delivered.
Refer to the sections below to verify and configure your DKIM settings.
title: Set Up Domain Keys Identified Mail (DKIM) to Authenticate Your Email

headings: Overview > Verify Your DKIM Configuration
body:
Usually, your domain's DKIM configuration is set by your IT rep or domain/mail administrator, but you can also check yourself using a tool such as MX Toolbox .
In its most basic form, DKIM can be verified using two elements:
- Your organization's domain name (for example, apollo.io )
- A DKIM selector is the text added with the domain to create a unique DNS record used during DKIM .
- This allows different systems, date ranges, or third-party services to create different signatures.
 
DKIM Selector? Wasn't she in Sonic Youth?
If a DKIM selector sounds more like the bass player from an 80s indie rock band, don't fret. Your IT or domain administrator typically creates this.
 
Within MX Toolbox (or a similar tool), enter your domain name and the selector in the fields. Then, click DKIM Lookup .
The DKIM status appears on the next screen.
If MX Toolbox is unable to find a DKIM record, refer to the section below to enable DKIM for your domain.
title: Set Up Domain Keys Identified Mail (DKIM) to Authenticate Your Email

headings: Overview > Enable DKIM for Your Domain
body:
If you've followed the steps above and found a DKIM record , there's no need to enable DKIM. If the tool did not find a record, your IT or domain administrator can work with the domain or email provider to enable and configure it for you—they should be familiar with the process.
Some popular providers are Google Workspace and Microsoft Office 365 . If you use these providers, you can refer to these links to confirm the settings and enable DKIM.
- Google Workspace:
- Before You Set Up DKIM
- Turn on DKIM for Your Domain
- Troubleshoot DKIM Issues
- Office 365:
- Use DKIM to validate outbound email sent from your custom domain
 
Google, DKIM, and You
If you're using Google Workspace for your domain, Google creates a DKIM key for you and puts it in your DNS records once your site is created. All you need to do is follow the steps in the " Turn on DKIM for Your Domain " article to configure your domain for DKIM .
 
 
Return to Sender
If you're the domain administrator, be extremely careful when you configure your DKIM method. Incorrect configurations can lead to your mail becoming undeliverable!
title: Set Up Domain Keys Identified Mail (DKIM) to Authenticate Your Email

headings: Overview > Fix Other Possible SPAM Issues
body:
DKIM configuration is only one way to confirm your emails get delivered. You should also set up SPF (Sender Policy Framework) records and DMARC (Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting & Conformance) policies to further validate your organization's domain and prevent e-mail bounces.
Read the Avoid SPAM Filters article for more information about potential SPAM concerns and best practices.
title: Set Up Domain Keys Identified Mail (DKIM) to Authenticate Your Email

headings: Overview
body:
Instead of deletion, you can archive unused sequences in Apollo. This feature lets you clean up the sequence list page without deleting content that you may want to reference later.
See the sections below for details about how to archive and unarchive Apollo sequences.
title: Archive Sequences

headings: Overview > Archive One Sequence
body:
From your sequence list, choose the Sequence you want to Archive .
Click the additional options button ( ... ) and then click Archive .
In the "Confirm Archive" modal, click Archive .
title: Archive Sequences

headings: Overview > Archive Multiple Sequences
body:
To archive more than 1 sequence at the same time, click the check boxes next to each sequences that you want to archive.
After you make your selections, click Archive .
In the "Confirm Archive" modal, click Archive .
 
Archiving Message
Please note, the modal will tell you how many sequences Apollo will archive.
Click Close .
title: Archive Sequences

headings: Overview > Unarchive Sequences
body:
You may accidentally archive a sequence. To unarchive a sequence, browse to the sequence list page and open the Status accordion.
Click the drop-down and then click Archived .
Click the additional options button ( ... ) next to an archived sequence and then click Unarchive .
title: Archive Sequences

headings: Watch the Video
title: Create and Edit a Contact or Company List

headings: Watch the Video > Read the Doc
title: Create and Edit a Contact or Company List

headings: Watch the Video > Overview
body:
Apollo Lists allow you to consolidate related contacts or companies in a common location so you can easily find them in a Search , use them in an Apollo Sequence , or Export them for use in third-party platforms.
Refer to the sections below for instructions on how to create and edit lists.
title: Create and Edit a Contact or Company List

headings: Watch the Video > Create a List of People
body:
Launch Apollo, click Search in the navbar, and then click People .
Click the checkbox next to each contact you want to add to your list or use batch selection.
Click the drop-down and then click Add to Lists .
In the "Add to Lists" modal, you can add the selected contacts to an existing list or create a new list.
 
Editing a List
Please note, you can add or remove contacts from a list at any time.
To create a new list, type the name of your list in the Add to Lists: text box then click Create new list [list name] .
Click Confirm to save your list.
To view your new list, click Search and then click Lists .
title: Create and Edit a Contact or Company List

headings: Watch the Video > Create a List of Companies
body:
Launch Apollo, click Search in the navbar, and then click Companies .
Click the checkbox next to each company that you want to add to your list.
Click the drop-down and then click Add to Lists .
To create a new list, type the name of your list in the Add to Lists: text box then click Create new list [list name] .
Click Add to Lists to save your list of companies.
To view your new list, click Search and then click Lists .
Click the Show drop-down and then click Companies Lists .
Your "Companies" list is viewable here.
title: Create and Edit a Contact or Company List

headings: Watch the Video > Managing a List
body:
To edit an existing list, click Search and then click Lists .
Click the additional options ( ... ) icon under the "Actions" column to either Edit the title of your list or Delete your list.
To view the contents of your list, click on the list name.
title: Create and Edit a Contact or Company List

headings: Watch the Video > Remove a Contact from a List
body:
To remove a contact from a list, click the checkbox next to the contact.
Click the drop-down and select Remove from Lists .
Select the checkbox for the list from which you would like your contact removed and click Remove Lists .
The contact is now removed from your list.
title: Create and Edit a Contact or Company List

headings: Overview
body:
Analyze the performance of your emails to gain valuable insights about your target audience. The more you evaluate what works and what doesn't, the more you can test and improve your Sequences to increase engagement.
Refer to the sections below for more information about the Email Analytics you can access in Apollo.
title: Access Apollo Email Analytics

headings: Overview > Access Apollo Email Analytics
body: When you send emails in Apollo, you can track your Open , Click , and Response rates. You can access this data from within a Sequence , from a Contact's profile page, or from the Analytics page.
title: Access Apollo Email Analytics

headings: Overview > Access Apollo Email Analytics > Access Campaign-Specific Email Data from a Sequence
body:
Launch Apollo and click Engage .
For a holistic view of all email data, click the Emails tab.
If you want to see the data for a specific User , Email , Sequence , or Contact , use the Filters on the left. Then, hover your mouse over the Status icons on the right to view more specific email insights.
You can also view email data from the Sequences tab.
To review the data from a specific Sequence , use the Filters on the left. Apollo displays the overall stats on the right.
Click a Sequence to see more in-depth statistics for it.
To take full advantage of Apollo Analytics , please refer to the Build and Access Reports in Apollo " article.
title: Access Apollo Email Analytics

headings: Overview > Access Apollo Email Analytics > Access Contact-Specific Email Data from a Contact's Profile Page
body:
Launch Apollo, click Search , and then click People .
Use the Search bar to find a specific contact .
Click the contact's name to open their profile page.
Click Show Activities .
Scroll through the Activities and hover your mouse over the Email Status icons to view the time and date that the contact Received , Opened , Clicked , or Replied to your email.
 
The Click Track Dilemma
Please note, in order to view whether a contact has clicked on any links that you have shared in your emails, you need to enable Click Tracking ; however, you should use this super power wisely! Click Tracking doesn't always play nicely with SPAM filters. For more information, please refer to the " Click Tracking in Apollo " article.
If you want to track who clicks and watches your Vidyard videos, it is much safer for you to do so with Vidyard Analytics instead. Refer to the " Access Vidyard Analytics " article for further details.
title: Access Apollo Email Analytics

headings: Watch the Video
title: Export Contacts from Apollo to a CSV

headings: Watch the Video > Read the Doc
title: Export Contacts from Apollo to a CSV

headings: Watch the Video > Read the Doc > Overview
body:
You can export contacts from Apollo to a CSV. This allows you to use your Apollo data in other tools in your workflow that support CSV imports.
Follow the instructions below to export enriched Apollo contacts to a CSV file or export all the saved contacts from a Search in one go.
title: Export Contacts from Apollo to a CSV

headings: Watch the Video > Read the Doc > Export Contacts from Apollo to a CSV
body:
Launch Apollo and click Search .
Apply filters to your search or load a saved Search to narrow down the list of contacts that you'd like to export.
Individually select contacts or use the bulk selection tools for the people who you would like to include in your CSV export.
Click Export .
 
Export Times May Vary
Please note, large exports that contain more than 1000 contacts may take several minutes to download.
In the "Export as CSV" modal, select whether you want to export emails for all of the contacts you selected or just those with verified emails.
If you want to adjust the export settings for CSV files in Apollo, click Edit Export CSV Settings .
When you're finished, click Confirm .
A new modal displays the export process for your file. When the export is complete, click Download to save your file.
If your file is larger, you can close the modal and check on the status of your export. Click Settings and then click Import & Exports . Select the CSV Exports tab.
title: Export Contacts from Apollo to a CSV

headings: Watch the Video > Export All Saved Contacts from Apollo to a CSV
body:
You can also export all the saved contacts from a Search at once. To do so, launch Apollo and click Search .
Apply filters to your search or load a saved search to narrow down the list of contacts that you'd like to export.
Click the Saved tab and then click the Export All icon.
Click Export All Records in the Export All modal that Apollo displays.
 
Maximum Records Per CSV File
Please note, Apollo exports saved contacts in batches of 50,000 records at a time. If you click export all for a list of more than 50,000 saved records, Apollo creates multiple CSVs.
You have now exported all saved contacts from Apollo to a CSV. When the export is complete, Apollo notifies you via email.
You can also check the status of the export directly in Apollo. Click Settings and then click Import & Exports . Select the CSV Exports tab.
Click the export to download the CSV file.
title: Export Contacts from Apollo to a CSV

headings: Overview
body:
Each sequence in Apollo has its own set of statistics.
This data is divided into two categories:
- Contact Stage statistics
- Email Tracking statistics
Refer to the sections below for additional details about each type.
title: Sequence Statistics Overview

headings: Overview > Contact Stage Statistics
body:
"Contact Stage" statistics are available on the lefthand side of the sequence screen.
 
Click for Additional Details
Please note, clicking on an individual statistic will bring you to the relevant stage in your sequence's Contacts tab.
"Contact Stage" statistics provide the following data points:
-
Active : The total number of contacts who are currently in the sequence
-
Paused : The total number of contacts who are currently in the sequence, but are paused on a certain step
-
Finished : The total number of contacts who have either completed the sequence or met a Mark sequence as finished trigger in the sequence's Settings tab
-
Bounced : The total number of contacts who had their email bounce after receiving a message in the sequence
-
Not sent : The total number of contacts who have met a Mark as failed when trigger in the sequence's Settings tab
title: Sequence Statistics Overview

headings: Overview > Email Tracking Statistics
body:
Potential Data Mismatch
Please note, the totals in the Delivered and Open categories will rarely line up with the Overview tab and the Emails tab. This is because the Emails tab shows stats relative to the emails themselves, rather than the contacts who were emailed. The Overview tab shows stats relative to those contacts. It's possible to deliver more than one message to a contact in a sequence and this explains the discrepancy.
"Email Tracking" statistics are available on the righthand side of the sequence screen.
 
Click for Additional Details
Please note, clicking on an individual statistic will bring you to the relevant stage in your sequence's Emails tab.
"Email Tracking" statistics provide the following data points:
-
Scheduled : The total number of contacts currently scheduled to receive a message in the sequence
-
Delivered : The total number of contacts who have been delivered at least one message in the sequence
-
Open : The total number of contacts who have opened at least one message in the sequence
-
Click : The total number of contacts who have clicked at least one link in the sequence's messages
-
Reply : The total number of contacts who have replied to at least one of the sequence's messages
-
Interested : The total number of contacts who were marked as interested after receiving one of the sequence's messages, or accepting a calendar invite
-
Opt out : The total number of contacts who have clicked an opt-out (unsubscribe) link in one of the sequence's messages
Aggregate statistics are determined by the total number of emails delivered in the sequence. The overall sequence percentages are calculated by dividing by the total number of emails delivered. When you hover your mouse over the percentages, you will then see the numerical count for that stat.
In the example above, the 82.2% open rate for the sequence is determined by the total number of open emails (106) divided by the total number of delivered emails (129). Email stats in individual sequence steps are calculated the same way as the aggregate—dividing by the total number of emails delivered for that one message.
 
Where is My Mind...er...Data?
Please note, if you delete contacts from your account, Apollo reflects this change in the statistics header under the "Emails" tab.
Apollo deletes the records of any emails that you sent to the deleted contacts; however, the “Overview” tab still displays statistics for every email that you have sent since you activated the sequence.
title: Sequence Statistics Overview

headings: Overview
body:
You may not want to potentially endanger your domain or send score, or worse, have your domain spam-blocked. For this reason, there may be instances where you need to show search results for people for which Apollo has a verified email. To do this, you can add an Email Status filter to your search.
 
Staying Safe!
Worried about getting SPAM-blocked? For more information about ways to protect your domain reputation, refer to the Avoid SPAM Filters article and the Email Verification: A Brief Introduction article.
Follow the steps below to apply the Email Status filter to your search results and only display contacts with verified emails.
title: Display People With Verified Emails

headings: Overview > Apply an "Email Status" Filter
body:
Launch Apollo and click Search in the navbar. Then, click People .
Click the Email Status accordion in the Filters pane.
Click the checkbox next to Verified .
Apollo displays the results on the right for the net new and saved contacts with verified emails.
 
It's Business Time!
Please note, this filter is currently only available when you set your primary email to "business." If your primary email is "personal," you cannot filter by email status. If you want to leverage the "verified" email status filter when you prospect in Apollo, consider changing your primary email back to "business." For more information about how to do so, please refer to the "Change Your Primary Email Type" section of the "Prospect with Personal and Business Emails" article.
title: Display People With Verified Emails

headings: Overview
body:
In Apollo, you can define Score Rules to automatically rank potential Contacts and Accounts based on the demographics and behaviors that are most important to you. This information defines your Scoring Model .
 
One Score to Rule Them All
Please note, Score Rules are not related to the Apollo Rules Engine . Score Rules define your Scoring Model while the Rules Engine helps you automate actions in Apollo that would otherwise require manual input. Read the Create Automation in the Rules Engine article if you're looking for information about the Rules Engine .
Before you proceed, you should first identify your Ideal Customer Profile (ICP) . With a clear idea of your ICP , you can use the Apollo Analytics tool to refine your data. You can then leverage Score Rules to rank the most important criteria for each ICP .
Apollo uses the Score Rules that you define to filter Contact and Account results so that they remain relevant to your ICP .
You can assign a numerical value to rank your criteria in order of importance. The higher the number you assign to a criterion, the more important Apollo ranks it. You can use the historical data from your Score Rules to inform how you adjust the rules to your liking.
For more information on how to create Score Rules and a Scoring Model , read the Create a Scoring Model article.
 
How'd I Even Get This Report?
Please note, each report in your Scoring Model references the opportunity-based metrics from the Apollo Analytics tool.
title: Scoring Engine Overview

headings: Overview > Create Multiple Scoring Models
body:
Your Scoring Model is a complete set of Score Rules that you enable in Apollo. You can create as many Scoring Models as you like.
However, only 1 Scoring Model can be active at a time.
title: Scoring Engine Overview

headings: Overview > Sync Your Scoring Model(s) With Salesforce
body:
You can sync the results from your Scoring Model with Salesforce. You need to map the relevant field from Apollo to Salesforce to sync this information.
 
Patience, Young Padawan
Please note, it can take Apollo up to 24 hours to sync the information from your Scoring Model with Salesforce.
For step-by-step instruction to sync Salesforce with your Scoring Model , read the Create a Scoring Model article.
title: Scoring Engine Overview

headings: Overview > Define Your Scoring Criteria
body:
Apollo breaks down the Scoring Rule filters into 2 types: Demographic and Behavioral . Refer to the table below for a list of the Account and Contact filters you can use to make a Scoring Model .
Score Type
